Problem:
Consider a system governed by the Laplace transform of a function \\( g(t) \\), denoted as \\( G(s) = \\mathcal{L}\\{g(t)\\}(s) \\). We investigate how the application of a convolution transformation defined by kernel \\( h(t) \\), with its Laplace transform \\( H(s) \\), affects the system.

If the convolution kernel \\( h(t) \\) is applied to the function \\( g(t) \\) resulting in \\( (g \\ast h)(t) \\), and then allowed to evolve under natural conditions, will the Laplace transform of the resultant function \\( \\mathcal{L}\\{(g \\ast h)(t)\\}(s) \\) at any \\( s \\) be the same as the product \\( G(s)H(s) \\)?
Explanation: The convolution theorem dictates that the Laplace transform of the convolution of two functions is the product of their individual Laplace transforms. Hence, \\( \\mathcal{L}\\{(g \\ast h)(t)\\}(s) = G(s)H(s) \\), reflecting the direct and predictable outcome of the convolution under natural conditions without additional manipulation.
